questions.text:
You are the Medical Officer-in-charge of a vaccination campaign in a District Hospital and you receive the vaccine given in the picture below. This vaccine can be stored in which of the following storage options?
  1. Walk-in cooler (WIC)
  2. Walk-in freezer (WIF)
  3. Ice lined refrigerator (ILR)
  4. Deep freezer 
  5. Domestic refrigerator
questions.solution:
The vaccine portrayed in the image given is the Covishield vaccine which has to be stored between +2 to +8°C. Walk-in cooler, Ice lined refrigerator and Domestic refrigerator maintains a temperature between +2 to +8°C.

Covid 19 AstraZeneca/Covishield vaccine storage and use guidelines :

    • Shelf life of 6 months stored in a refrigerator between 2 to 8°C
    • Once removed from the refrigerator, may be stored between 2 to 25°C for up to 6 hours
    • Once punctured, the vial must be used within 6 hours
    • Must not be frozen
    • Keep vials in the outer carton to protect from light

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with type 2 neurofibromatosis was referred to the Department of Otorhinolaryngology for hearing rehabilitation after excision of bilateral acoustic neuromas. The surgery notes mentioned that the 8th nerve was severed during the surgery. After further evaluation, a decision to insert an implant to aid hearing was made. Where will the implant be placed?
questions.solution:
The implant of choice, in this case, would be an auditory brainstem implant (ABI), which is placed in the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle. It is designed to directly stimulate the cochlear nuclear complex in the brainstem.

This type of implant is required when cranial nerve VIII has been severed in surgery for vestibular schwannomas. In unilateral acoustic neuromas, ABI is not necessary as hearing is possible from the contralateral side. The receiver or stimulator has a removable magnet so that MRI can be safely performed if required.

ABIs help in communication, awareness, and recognition of environmental sounds, but are not as efficient as multichannel cochlear implants. 

Cochlear implants are electronic devices for severe to profound SNHL and those who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. The electrode array is placed within the scala tympani of the cochlea. A prerequisite for this is that cranial nerve VIII and the higher auditory pathway should be intact.

 

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient was brought to you by his wife, who complains that he tends to collect unwanted things and does not allow these things to be thrown away. She shows you the following photograph of their house, which has gradually become this way over the last 8 years. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

choices.text: Driven by an obsessive fear of losing important items
Patients do not perceive this as a problem
Full remission is achieved after treatment
CBT is the most effective management

questions.solution:
The image shows the house of a person with hoarding disorder. Full remission is rarely achieved, as patients lack insight into their behavior. 

The disorder is characterized by acquiring and not discard­ing things that are of little or no value, resulting in excessive clutter of living spaces, driven by an obsessive fear of losing important items that the person believes may be useful in the future. It was con­sidered a subtype of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) but is now considered to be a separate diagnostic entity. 

Most hoarders do not perceive their hoarding as a problem and believe it is a reasonable part of their identity. There is an inability to organize their possessions and they often hoard to avoid making decisions about discarding items. Patients with hoarding disorder overemphasize the importance of recall­ing information and possessions.

Commonly hoarded items include newspapers, mail, magazines, clothes, bags, books, and notes. Clutter accumulated from hoarding can lead to deaths from fires or patients being crushed by their possessions. It may also attract pest infesta­tions.

The most effective treatment for the disorder is cognitive-behavioral therapy which involves training in decision making and categorizing exposure and habituation to discarding, and cognitive restructuring. This includes both office and in-home sessions. It is less respon­sive to classic treatments for OCD such as exposure therapy and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRis).

Related Pearl: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Key points:

  • Most common:
    • Obsession: Contamination
    • Compulsion: Checking, cleaning
  • Treatment: Exposure and Response prevention - 1st line, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy(CBT), CBT with ERP, Pharmacotherapy.
  • Drug of choice: High dose SSRI
  • Treatment in nonresponsive patients: Clomipramine or antipsychotic augmentation
  • Treatment of severe or refractory cases: Deep brain stimulation

questions.text: While collecting samples from a patient scheduled to undergo a blood transfusion, which of the following vacutainers will you use to collect blood for cross-matching, and which cannula will you use for blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Lavender/purple vacutainer (EDTA) vacutainer is used for routine hematological studies and green cannula (18G) is used for blood transfusion.

EDTA is the additive present in purple vacutainer, which chelates calcium and other metal ions needed for the coagulation cascade. It is routinely used for most routine hematological investigations because it preserves the morphology of cellular components.

Though green cannula(18G) can be used for blood transfusion. Grey (16G) is preferred in case multiple transfusion or rapid fluid infusion is necessary.

questions.text: A three-year-old female child was brought by her mother with complaints of fever, vomiting, and poor sensorium.  At admission, the child was in early shock with a GCS of 8/15. She had multiple healed scars and fresh bruises all over her body. Her mother attributed each injury to a different event in the past and denies any recent injury. A CT scan of her head revealed an epidural hemorrhage and a fracture of the skull. Which type of fracture is most likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical case suggests non-accidental injuries or child abuse, and the most likely fracture among the given options, that will be seen in a 3-year-old child with a history of abuse is a Diastatic fracture.

Diastatic fractures refer to fractures in which the fracture line involves the separation of one or more cranial sutures. These are commonly seen in children and are often associated with epidural or subdural hemorrhage. The sagittal suture between the two parietal bones is the most common site of these fractures.

They result from a large or broad impact to the head, as seen in blows, falls, industrial or vehicular accidents. It is also seen in circumstances where the victim is swung by their legs against a wall or an immovable object.

 

Other options:

Option A: Ring fracture is a type of fissured fracture that encircles the base of the skull around the foramen magnum. It is seen when:

  • The force of fall is transmitted upwards through the spinal column, after fall from a height on to the feet or buttocks.

  • The vault of the skull is driven against the spine, when a heavy load falls over the vertex, after a fall from a height onto the head after a heavy blow over the vertex.

  • Violent twisting of the head on the spine, shearing the vault from the base

Option B: Expressed fractures are massive fragmentation/shattering of the skull. The pieces may lie outside the cranium in the pericranial tissues, orbits, or physically outside the head. They occur due to massive trauma involving contact or close-range firearm or blast injuries. 

Option D: Gutter fractures refer to furrows in the outer table of the skull, as a result of a blow by a missile from a rifled firearm. These may be accompanied by comminuted depressed fractures of the inner table of the skull.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents with episodes of intermittent right upper abdominal pain for the past few months. She underwent cholecystectomy a year back. Investigations showed elevated AST and ALT levels and imaging revealed a dilated common bile duct with prolonged biliary drainage time. What is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?

AST - Aspartate aminotransferase
ALT - Alanine aminotransferase
HIDA - Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid
ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with manometry of the biliary and pancreatic sphincters is the gold standard for its diagnosis.

Sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia or dysfunction (SOD) is characterized by abdominal pain, biliary or pancreatic duct dilatation due to abnormal function of the sphincter of Oddi.

Clinical types include biliary and pancreatic SOD.

Biliary type presents with biliary pain, raised liver enzymes, and/or dilation of the bile duct and/or evidence of delayed emptying on biliary imaging. It should be excluded in patients with post-cholecystectomy syndrome. Pancreatic SOD presents as recurrent episodes of unexplained acute pancreatitis.

CT and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) can demonstrate dilatation of the biliary and pancreatic ducts. MRCP with intravenous secretin injection demonstrates dilatation of the pancreatic duct due to increased sphincter pressures. Endoscopic ultrasound can also be used. HIDA scan will show delayed biliary transit.

The gold standard investigation is ERCP with manometry and is indicated in disabling pain, when noninvasive investigations fail to demonstrate structural abnormalities and when conservative therapy fails. Basal sphincter pressure higher than 40 mm Hg is suggestive of SOD.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography. It involves the use of a side-viewing endoscope which is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla.

It can be a therapeutic and diagnostic modality specifically for viewing the distal biliary tree. The most common indication for therapeutic ERCP is the relief of biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures.  

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: A 30-year-old man suffered a traumatic brain injury after a road traffic accident in which he fell from his motorcycle. He was brought to the emergency department where he was stabilized and a CT scan was performed which showed extensive damage to the medial undersides of both occipital lobes and the inferior medioventral surfaces of the temporal lobes. When he meets his family, which among the following is likely to happen?

choices.text: Unable to understand what they are saying

questions.solution:
Lesions to the medial underside of both occipital lobes and the inferior medioventral surfaces of the temporal lobes cause prosopagnosia, which is the inability to identify faces.

The right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals represents the storage and recognition of faces. Damage to this area can cause prosopagnosia. Patients with prosopagnosia can recognize people by their voices and also show autonomic responses when they see familiar faces. The left hemisphere is also involved, but the right hemisphere plays a major role.

Other options:

Option A: The inability to understand is seen in Wernicke's aphasia. The patient is not able to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that do not make sense. It occurs due to a lesion in the superior temporal gyrus.

Option B: The inability to recognize familiar voices is called phonagnosia. It is seen after damage to the inferior and lateral parietal regions of the right hemisphere.

Option D: Difficulty in forming words(verbal or written) is seen in Broca's aphasia or motor aphasia. This occurs as a result of a lesion in Broca's area in the frontal lobe. Affected individuals have slow speech.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was taken to the emergency department with palpitations and restlessness after using a salbutamol inhaler 15 times in one hour following an asthma attack. Her chest examination was clear on auscultation, and cardiac examination showed tachycardia with a regular rhythm, without murmurs. What features are likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Salbutamol toxicity can cause muscle tremors due to stimulation of β2-adrenergic receptors in skeletal muscle. It is the most common side effect. The risk is higher with elderly patients and those with COPD.

Salbutamol is a relatively selective β2- adrenergic receptor agonist. In overdose, receptor specificity may be lost and stimulation of cardiac β2-receptors may cause tachycardia, cardiac ischemia, and arrhythmias. It causes hypokalemia (option C) by stimulating β2-receptors of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump in the skeletal muscle, shifting K+ intracellularly. This can produce ECG changes such as flattening and inversion of T waves (option A), QT prolongation, and U waves. 

Acute salbutamol toxicity may cause lactic acidosis. β2-adrenergic stimulation increases gluconeogenesis and lipolysis. This causes increased plasma glucose, leading to increased conversion of pyruvate and lactate. Overdose can result in hyperglycemia (option B), lactic acidosis, and cardiac arrhythmias. 

Other adverse effects include hypoxemia and metabolic effects such as an increase in free fatty acids and insulin. Desensitization is noted in the long-term use of salbutamol.

questions.text: Two brothers presented with bilateral painless progressive visual loss. After a thorough examination and investigation, the diagnosis of a rare inherited disease was made. The pedigree chart shown in the image below was drawn to explain which family members may be affected (colored red). Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows mitochondrial inheritance, and the condition showing this pattern of inheritance is Leber optic neuropathy.

The mitochondrial pattern of inheritance is when the mother is affected and the father is normal, which leads to all their children (both male and female) being affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.

The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance, as the disease is transmitted through the affected mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is derived from the maternal mitochondria. The ovum contains several mitochondria, while the spermatozoa have very few mitochondria, if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is entirely derived from the ovum.

Therefore, while the affected mother transmits the disease to all the offspring (both male and female), only the daughters of the affected mother can further transmit the disease.

 

Characteristic features of mitochondrial inheritance are as follows:

The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, organs that are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation are the ones most affected in diseases due to mutations in mtDNA. These organs include the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys.

There are several thousands of copies of mtDNA in each mitochondrion, of which only a few copies are affected in case of mutation. Therefore, a diseased individual possesses copies of both wild-type mtDNA and mutant mtDNA in each mitochondrion. This phenomenon is called heteroplasmy. 

The disease manifests if a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA are present in the mitochondria, which can lead to oxidative dysfunction; this phenomenon is called the threshold effect. In most cases, this threshold effect is reached in the organs as mentioned above.

Also, during cell division, the wild and mutant copies of the mtDNA are unequally distributed among the daughter cells. As a result, the expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ.

Other options:

Option A: Ocular albinism is inherited as X-linked recessive or autosomal recessive disease.

Option B: Retinitis pigmentosa may be inherited as autosomal dominant, recessive, or X-linked based on the involved genes.

Option C: Leber congenital amaurosis is inherited as an autosomal recessive inheritance.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-month-old baby for a routine evaluation. On examination, a loud, harsh pan systolic murmur was heard on auscultation over the lower left sternal border. There was no cyanosis or finger clubbing. Echocardiography revealed a defect of 8 mm in the membranous part of the interventricular septum. The presence of which of the following would not be a valid indication for surgery?

choices.text: Large defect not controlled by medication
Large defect with failure to thrive

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a loud, harsh pansystolic murmur, with the given echocardiography findings, is suggestive of a ventricular septal defect (VSD). The presence of Eisenmenger syndrome is a contraindication for surgery. 

Ventricular septal defects are the most common congenital heart lesions. 90% are located in the membranous part of the septum with variable extension into the muscular part. 

Children may present at 6–10 weeks of age with congestive cardiac failure, or with palpitations, exertional dyspnoea, and frequent chest infections when they are older. On examination, a loud pan systolic murmur is heard at the left sternal border with a systolic thrill. S2 may be widely split with P2 accentuation. S3 may be audible at the apex.

Muscular VSDs are likely to close spontaneously. Medical management consists of control of cardiac failure, treatment of infections, treatment of anemia, and infective endocarditis. 

Surgery in VSD mainly helps to relieve congestive cardiac failure which manifests as a failure to thrive in an infant. The main aim of performing surgery in VSD is to get the symptoms of heart failure in control and to prevent the development of pulmonary vascular disease.

Indications for surgical closure of a VSD:

  • Large defects with clinical symptoms that cannot be controlled medically
  • Large defects with pulmonary hypertension, controlled by medication
  • Patients older than 2 years with a pulmonary flow of more than twice the systemic flow
  • Patients with a supracristal VSD of any size (because of the high risk for aortic valve regurgitation)
  • Associated pulmonary stenosis.

Surgical treatment is not indicated in

  • Patients with a small VSD (exception subpulmonic/supracristal VSD with aortic valve prolapse)
  • Severe, uncontrolled pulmonary arterial hypertension with a significant right-to-left shunt (Eisenmenger syndrome)

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presented with chronic pain in the lower back and knees. On physical examination, there were black pigmentary deposits on the sclera of both eyes and on the fingers and nailbeds. The urine turned black on exposure to Benedict's reagent and showed large amounts of a particular metabolite which is responsible. Identify the metabolite from the image below
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of alkaptonuria, which is characterised by excretion of the metabolite homogentisate (marked as 2 in the flowchart) in urine.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism. It occurs due to a defect in homogentisate oxidase (which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate) leading to the accumulation of homogentisate. The excreted homogentisate in urine makes it appear black when it gets oxidized on exposure to air or an oxidizing agent.

Accumulation of oxidized homogentisic acid pigment (benzoquinone acetate) in joints and connective tissues leads to arthritis and connective tissue pigmentation respectively. This is known as ochronosis. Pigmentation of heart valves, larynx, tympanic membranes, and skin, with occasional renal pigment calculi, can also be seen.

Most patients are diagnosed early based on the darkening of urine with standing or the addition of alkali. Around the age of 30 years, gray-brown pigmentation of sclera and generalized darkening of the concha, anthelix and helix of the ear is seen.Some patients present in middle age with a degenerative joint disease (ochronotic arthritis) with pain, stiffness, and limitation of motion of the lower back, hips, knees, and shoulders. Small joints are usually spared.

Treatment:

  • Symptomatic treatment with pain medications, spinal surgery, and arthroplasty 
  • Ascorbic acid and protein restriction 
  • Nitisinone - reduces urinary excretion of homogentisic acid and delays progression of the disease.

The images below show pigmentation of the skin and an x-ray of the spine that shows calcification of intervertebral discs, both symptoms of ochronosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presented to the outpatient department with complaints of burning pain and altered sensation in her right hand. She mentions that the pain worsens at night and in order to relieve it, she sleeps with her arm hanging over the side of the bed. On examination, symptoms are reproduced when the patient presses her wrists against each other in flexion for 60 seconds, and when direct pressure is applied for 30 seconds on the point shown in the image. Identify the other features that can be present as the condition progresses.

choices.text: Tingling on resisted flexion of middle proximal interphalangeal joint

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with pain and abnormal sensations in the hand, along with positive Phalen's test and Durkan's test suggest Carpal tunnel syndrome. In late cases, there can be weakness of thumb abduction. 

Carpal tunnel syndrome(CTS) is a condition in which the median nerve gets entrapped in the carpal tunnel. Patients present with burning pain and paresthesia of the first three digits, and the radial half of the fourth digit. The symptoms are worse at night and are relieved by shaking the arm or hanging it by the side of the bed. It may progress to weakness and clumsiness of the hand.

Tests for CTS -

  • Durkan's test is the most specific test for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In Durkan's test, direct median nerve compression elicits paresthesias and pain.
  • Phalen's test - Elicited by holding the wrist flexed fully. The appearance of sensory symptoms within 60 seconds implies a positive test.
  • Tinel's sign - Sensory symptoms reproduced by percussing over the median nerve implies a positive test.

In advanced cases, there is wasting of the thenar muscles, weakness of thumb abduction and decreased sensations in the median nerve territory.

The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies are done to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome.

In cases of mild clinical symptoms, splinting or glucocorticoid injections may be first tried. Surgical division of the transverse carpal ligament is recommended for severe CTS or if non-surgical management fails.

 

Phalen’s test- It is a provocative clinical test for carpal tunnel syndrome. It is used to detect the compression of the median nerve in carpal tunnel syndrome.

The patient is asked to actively place the wrist in complete but forced flexion. The test is considered positive if tingling and numbness are produced in the median nerve distribution of the hand within 60 seconds.

The given image shows Phalen’s test:

Other options:

Option B: Inability to perform the 'OK sign' is seen in anterior interosseous nerve syndrome. The patient is unable to pinch with the thumb and index finger joints flexed like a ring (OK sign) due to weakness of the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus.

Options C and D: Tingling on resisted elbow flexion and on resisted flexion of the middle proximal interphalangeal joint is seen in pronator syndrome. This occurs when the median nerve is compressed beneath one of the structures around the elbow like the ligament of Struthers (a connection between the medial epicondyle and the humerus), the bicipital aponeurosis, the origins of pronator teres, or flexor digitorum superficialis.

questions.text: A 22-year old man was admitted with complaints of recurrent abdominal pain, bloating, and vomiting. On examination, there was fullness in the epigastrium and hyper peristaltic bowel sounds. The upper GI barium study showed a dilated stomach and second part of the duodenum, with the third part of the duodenum cut off. There were no intrinsic mucosal abnormalities.  Intra-operatively,  it was seen that the third part of the duodenum was compressed between two blood vessels. Identify the vessels responsible for this condition from the image below.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with intraoperative findings is suggestive of Superior mesenteric artery syndrome, where the third part of the duodenum gets compressed between the superior mesenteric artery (marked as B) and the abdominal aorta (marked as D).

 

The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) originates from the abdominal aorta below the coeliac trunk at the level of the L1 vertebra. 

It descends anterior to the uncinate process of the pancreas and the third part of the duodenum. The left renal vein separates it from the aorta posteriorly.

The branches of SMA include:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

The jejunal and ileal branches form vascular arcades within the small bowel mesentery, the last of which form the marginal artery of the small intestine.

Superior Mesenteric artery syndrome occurs due to the compression of the third part of the duodenum between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. The most characteristic presentation is postprandial epigastric fullness with pain and bilious vomiting. The diagnosis is mostly clinical with radiologic evidence of obstruction on Barium studies and CT scan. Treatment is by surgery (either laparoscopic or open method) 

The image below is a CT scan of the pelvis and abdomen showing duodenal compression (arrow) by the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery.

questions.text: A child aged 10 years presented with perianal pruritus which is worse in night. Routine stool examination didn't reveal parasite cysts or eggs. The following examination is done to recover eggs which are non-bile stained. Identify the organism causing the infection.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing scotch tape method to collect perianal egg deposition by (Enterobius vermicularis) is  suggestive of infestation with Pinworm 

Characteristics of Pinworm egg:

  • It is colorless, non-bile stained.
  • It floats in the saturated salt solution.
  • The egg is planoconvex. Eggshell is double layered and relatively thick, though transparent.

Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens.

Scotch tape method involves:

  1. Take a clear cellophane tape almost 4 cm long
  2. Hold it in such a way(or make a loop) so that sticky surface faces upwards or towards the perianal skin.
  3. Place the sticky surface of tap in the perianal area momentarily
  4. Place the sticky surface down on the glass slide. Examine under microscope.

Other eggs that can be collected by scotch tape method are Taenia solium, Taenia saginata, and Schistosoma mansoni. 

Other eggs which are non-bile stained can be remembered as NEHA - Necator americanus, Enterobius vermicularis, Hymenolepsis nana, Ancylostoma duodenale.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with anhidrosis and enophthalmos. Examination reveals miosis along with mild ptosis. You decide to correct the ptosis by performing a Fasanella-Servat operation, by resecting which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's syndrome and the associated mild ptosis in this condition can be corrected by resecting Muller's muscle.

Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to the paralysis of Muller's muscle.

Fasanella-Servat operation is indicated in cases having mild ptosis(< 2 mm) and good levator function. In this surgery, the upper tarsal border along with its attached Muller’s muscle and conjunctiva are resected.

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 9×10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of Phyllodes tumor or cystosarcoma phyllodes of the breast.

Phyllodes tumor, also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes, presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition.

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes or as serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some of the low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors, and malignant type- Mastectomy

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor.

 

Other options:

Giant fibroadenomas are usually seen in the early reproductive years. These are benign solid encapsulated tumors. It is a slow-growing tumor and presents as a painless lump in the breast.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory cancer is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics. Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Patients with inflammatory carcinoma usually have a history revealing the rapid onset of the disease with progression over weeks to 3 months.

The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without an underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema, edema, and warmth of the breast as a result of lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with palpitations and a heart rate of 150/minute. An ECG is done which is shown below. If the blood pressure is normal, what is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer IV dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker

questions.solution:
The ECG showing sawtooth flutter waves along with the clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of atrial flutter. The next best step is to administer an intravenous (IV) beta-blocker for rate control as the patient is hemodynamically stable.

The initial management of atrial flutter targets rate control through IV atrioventricular (AV) nodal blocking agents. These include beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCB) such as verapamil and diltiazem. Intravenous ibutilide, a class III antiarrhythmic agent can be used for rhythm control.

If the patient presents with severe symptoms or is hemodynamically unstable, electrical cardioversion is the first step. If the episode duration is > 48 hours, or if the patient has an increased risk of thromboembolic stroke based on the CHAD2DS2 -VASc scoring system, anticoagulation must be provided before the cardioversion. The drugs which can be used are direct oral anticoagulants (DOAC) such as apixaban, edoxaban, and rivaroxaban. Dabigatran, an antithrombin inhibitor, and warfarin, a vitamin K antagonist can also be used. 

The first episode does not warrant the continuation of antiarrhythmic drugs after conversion to sinus rhythm. In recurrent episodes, sotalol or amiodarone may be used.

At least 4 weeks of anticoagulation therapy is carried out after electrical or chemical cardioversion, as done in atrial fibrillation. Patients with risk factors for thromboembolism should continue it for longer. The definitive treatment is catheter ablation for recurrent cases.

The ECG shows characteristic sawtooth flutter waves due to the atrial activity in the inferior leads ( leads II, III, and aVF). Positive P waves are seen in lead V1. Conduction of more than 230 impulses/ minute through the AV node is not possible in adults. Hence a 2:1 or greater AV block is almost always associated. So patients present with tachycardia of 130-150 beats/minute. Typically, the atrial rate is around 240-300/minute.

Atrial flutter is more commonly seen in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or structural heart disease. Symptoms include palpitations, dizziness, and fatigue.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Miller laryngoscopic blade. 

A laryngoscope is an instrument used for examination of the larynx and facilitation of tracheal intubation. It has three components: the handle, the blade, and the light source. The Macintosh and Miller blades are the most popularly used blades.

Miller's blade is a straight blade. Its curve begins 2 inches from the tip. It is inserted using the para-glossal technique. This technique avoids contact with the maxillary incisors and provides maximal tongue control.

It is used in:

  • Neonates, infants, and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Macintosh blade is a sharply curved blade with a large flange. It is inserted in the right side of the mouth, and the flange is used to sweep the tongue to the left. The blade is advanced and positioned in the vallecula. Advantages of a curved blade include:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to dermatology OPD with the given condition. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing hyperpigmented macules on the face is diagnostic of melasma.

Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis and is manifested by hyperpigmented macules on the face which become more pronounced after sun exposure.

Hyper-melanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, forehead, chin and mandible region. 

Melasma is more common in women (90%) and in ages between 20-40 years. It is frequently seen in women on oral contraceptives.

Melasma is more chronic and requires treatment with depigmenting agents like:

  • Hydroquinone (reduces tyrosinase activity)
  • Kojic acid (tyrosinase inhibitor)
  • Chemical peels
  • Kligman's triple combination- Topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + corticosteroid compound cream [First line]

Other Options:

Option A: Systemic lupus erythematosus is characterised by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

Option C: The same facial melanosis in pregnant women is called Chloasma or mask of pregnancy. Only the terms used differ. Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Chloasma usually resolves after pregnancy.

Option D: Rosacea mainly involves the convexities of the face and presents as erythemato-telangiectatic type over the cheeks.
